contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox scientist |name = Ernst Ruska |image = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1906|12|25|df=y}} |birth_name = Ernst August Friedrich Ruska |birth_place = [[Heidelberg]], [[German Empire|Germany]] |residence = |nationality = [[Germany]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1988|5|27|1906|12|25|df=y}} |death_place = [[West Berlin]], [[Germany]] |field = [[Physics]] |work_institution = [[Fritz Haber Institute]]<br>[[Technical University of Berlin]] |alma_mater = [[Technical University of Munich]] |doctoral_advisor = [[Max Knoll]] |known_for = [[Electron microscope|Electron Microscopy]] |prizes = [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] (1986) |religion = Catholic |footnotes = }} [[Image:Ernst Ruska Electron Microscope - Deutsches Museum - Munich-edit.jpg|thumb|right|Electron microscope constructed by Ernst Ruska in 1933]] '''Ernst August Friedrich Ruska''' (25 December 1906 – 27 May 1988)<ref>His Nobel bio claims he died on 25 May, while the Ruska memorial site says 27 May</ref> was a [[Germany|German]] [[physics|physicist]] who won the [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] in 1986 for his work in [[electron optics]], including the design of the first [[electron microscope]]. ==Life and career== Ruska was born in [[Heidelberg]]. He was educated at the [[Technical University of Munich]] from 1925 to 1927 and then entered the [[Technical University of Berlin]], where he posited that [[microscope]]s using [[electrons]], with wavelengths 1000 times shorter than those of light, could provide a more detailed picture of an object than a microscope utilizing light, in which magnification is limited by the size of the wavelengths. In 1931, he demonstrated that a magnetic coil could act as an electron lens, and used several coils in a series to build the first [[electron microscope]] in 1933. After completing his PhD in 1933, Ruska continued to work in the field of electron optics, first at Fernseh Ltd in Berlin-Zehlendorf, and then from 1937 at [[Siemens|Siemens-Reiniger-Werke AG]]. At Siemens, he was involved in developing the first commercially produced electron microscope in 1939. As well as developing the technology of electron microscopy while at Siemens, Ruska also worked at other scientific institutions, and encouraged Siemens to set up a laboratory for visiting researchers, which was initially headed by Ruska's brother [[Helmut Ruska|Helmut]], a medical doctor who developed the use of the electron microscope for medical and biological applications. After leaving Siemens in 1955, Ruska served as director of the Institute for Electron Microscopy of the [[Fritz Haber Institute]] until 1974. Concurrently, he served at the institute and as professor at the [[Technical University of Berlin]] from 1957 until his retirement in 1974. In 1986, he was awarded half of the Nobel Prize in Physics for his many achievements in electron optics; [[Gerd Binnig]] and [[Heinrich Rohrer]] won a quarter each for their design of the [[scanning tunneling microscope]]. He died in [[West Berlin]] in 1988. ==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1986/press.html Nobel Prize press release] *[http://nobelprize.org/physics/laureates/1986/ruska-autobio.html Ernst Ruska's official Nobel autobiography] *[http://ernst.ruska.de/daten_e/mainframe_e.html Website containing memorial information published by the Ruska family] {{Nobel Prize in Physics Laureates 1976-2000}} {{Authority control|VIAF=40173810}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Ruska, Ernst | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = German physicist | DATE OF BIRTH = 25 December 1906 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Heidelberg]], [[German Empire|Germany]] | DATE OF DEATH = 27 May 1988 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[West Berlin]], [[Germany]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ruska, Ernst}} [[Category:1906 births]] [[Category:1988 deaths]] [[Category:People from Heidelberg]] [[Category:German physicists]] [[Category:Technical University Munich alumni]] [[Category:Nobel laureates in Physics]] [[Category:German inventors]] [[Category:German Nobel laureates]] [[Category:Microscopists]] [[Category:Max Planck Society people]] [[Category:Recipients of the Albert Lasker Award for Basic Medical Research]] [[Category:Physicists]]
